title: How to bag private equity profits with an investment trust
text:
Trainline was one of the most successful flotations of a private company this year

Stock market investors may be missing out on the best years of a growing company’s success.

This is partly because of the boom in private equity since the turn of the century.

Many companies now choose to raise ‘expansion capital’ from private equity funds and only float on public stock markets later on – to ‘crystallise’ a high share valuation and enable early-stage investors to exit.

Just look at Trainline, the rail bookings website.

It was one of the most successful flotations of a private company this year when it floated about 57 per cent of the business on the UK stock market in June.

It made fortunes for several private equity firms, including KKR (its biggest shareholder) which earlier this month cashed in a serious chunk of shares netting it hundreds of millions of pounds – a significant return on its investment.

Individual stock market investors in such situations can often be left to sit on the sidelines and watch private equity fat cats running off with the cream of the returns.

But there is a way for ordinary investors to grab a share of the private equity action for themselves.

The main route is via an investment trust – a stock market-listed fund that invests in private equity companies. They have proved popular and profitable, apart from a disastrous period during the financial crisis a decade ago.

Annabel Brodie-Smith, of the Association of Investment Companies, says: ‘Over the past ten years, private equity investment companies have generated returns for investors averaging 300 per cent – more than double the 125 per cent gain an investor would have made from the FTSE All-Share over the same period.’

She adds: ‘Businesses are choosing to stay private for longer which means that in many cases the lion’s share of their growth has already happened by the time they list on a stock market. Reflecting this shift, more investment trusts are investing in private companies.’

Many investors have exposure to private equity perhaps in their Isas or pensions without even realising it via big, popular investment trusts such as Scottish Mortgage and F&C, which have allocated some of their portfolios to this area.

Private equity is not a one-way bet. Unquoted companies can be volatile and illiquid – just ask investors in Neil Woodford’s Equity Income fund who cannot get out of the fund because the manager is struggling to sell such investments quickly.

Investment trusts are more flexible than funds for ordinary investors as they can always sell their shares – even if they don’t much like the price they sell them for.

There are about 20 investment trusts that focus on private equity.

Ryan Hughes, of broker AJ Bell, says: ‘The investment trust structure is well suited to private equity investment because the fund manager doesn’t need to worry about the daily buying and selling of the shares by investors. Instead they can focus on making long-term investments and managing the portfolio of companies they have invested in.’

What these different trusts invest in varies dramatically so it is important to research them carefully and be aware that charges are higher than more conventional trusts.

The best-known private equity specialist is 3i, which has been around since the 1940s and listed on the stock market in 1994.

Hughes says: ‘Today it has a market value of £10billion and a portfolio of some 30 companies spread across the world including both Belfast Airport and Audley Travel in the UK. It could make a useful first holding for those wanting private equity exposure.’

While 3i invests directly in companies, other ‘fund of fund’ style investment trusts – for example Standard Life Private Equity – spread their money around different private equity managers.

Others co-invest in direct deals alongside so-called private equity sponsors who invite other investors to join the deal. This is the strategy applied by NB Private Equity Partners.

Hughes says: ‘The likes of Pantheon Ventures and HarbourVest have significant assets and look to build a diversified basket of private equity approaches right across the world to spread risk.

'Pantheon’s share price is up nearly 100 per cent in the past five years while HarbourVest is up nearly 150 per cent. Both have long pedigrees of investing in this area which is a key requirement when looking at private equity.’

The fund of funds approach can be attractive as you end up with automatic diversification both by country and by business strategy. But Jason Hollands, of wealth manager Tilney, warns: ‘The pitfalls are high total costs through multiple layers of fund costs and performance fees.’

While high returns are possible from private equity investments investors need to be comfortable with the greater risks involved.

The AIC’s Brodie-Smith says: ‘Private companies are often at an earlier stage of their development where things can easily go wrong.

‘However, the share structure of an investment trust allows the fund manager to take a long-term view. They are never forced sellers which makes them an ideal way to invest in these hard-to-trade assets.’

MAKE SURE YOU’RE IN FOR THE LONG TERM

Private equity should be considered a long-term investment as investors will inevitably endure plenty of volatility along the way – but the rewards can be worth the wait. But to be safe, do not devote more than about 10 per cent of a portfolio to the sector.

NB Private Equity Partners is a strong performing investment trust. Many of its current investments, which include office supplies business Staples and insurance brokerage USI, are US-based and because most have been made since 2016, there is the potential for exit windfalls.

Its past performance has been attractive – over ten years £1,000 has grown to £5,280.

Recently appointed chairman William Maltby says: ‘Management incentives are much better aligned with private equity as they have the financial incentives to build value.’

The fund’s co-manager, Peter Von Lehe, adds: ‘The perception is that all private equity investments end up in a flotation – or initial public offering. In fact, it is more common for an investment to be sold to a strategic partner or another private equity firm.’

Maltby has been brought in to market the trust and hopefully shrink the discount on the share price.

A discount (or premium) is the measure of the share price versus the underlying assets – with NB Private Equity Partners currently trading at a 25 per cent discount. This makes it cheap for purchasers of its shares but anyone buying must hope that the discount will reduce.
